questions.text: Dose reduction is required in renal failure with all except:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Doxycycline

Highyeild:

Dose reduction is needed in case of following conditions: Drug causing nephrotoxicity as adverse drug reaction Drug excreted through renal route Amphotericin B is most nephrotoxic among antifungals. Even liposomal preparations of amphotericin B (c AMB, LAMB, ABCD, ABLC) are nephrotoxic, though less as compared to conventional Amphotericin B. More than 90% of vancomycin is excreted through glomerular filtration. In case of renal failure, there may be less excretion which leads to toxicity of Vancomycin due to its striking accumulation in body (ototoxicity, nephrotoxicity, red man syndrome). Half-life of vancomycin can increase to 6–10 days in case of anephric patients. Gentamicin is an aminoglycoside. Aminoglycosides are most potent to cause both ototoxicity and nephrotoxicity. Aminoglycosides are excreted almost entirely by glomerular filtration. High concentration of aminoglycosides is found in otic fluid and by virtue of the process of elimination: high concentration is found in urinary tract. Dose modification required in renal failure. Cockcroft–Gault equation C Cr = creatinine clearance (expressed in mL/min); S Cr = serum creatinine (expressed in mg/dL) Among tetracyclines, minocycline and doxycycline are safe in renal impairment cases. Doxycycline does not cause nephrotoxicity and is excreted through bile. Other tetracyclines can cause Fanconi syndrome characterized by toxic metabolite accumulation (tetracyclines and epihydrotetracyclines). So, answer is Doxycycline.

questions.text: Low apparent volume of distribution (aVd) indicates:

options.label: A
options.text: Drug is not extensively distributed in organs and tissues

questions.correct_answer: A. Drug is not extensively distributed in organs and tissues
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Drug is not extensively distributed in organs and tissues

Highyeild:

Volume of distribution (V d ) is defined as ratio of the amount of drug in the body and the plasma concentration of drug (Cp) V d = Total dose administered to patient/C p Volume of distribution can be determined by various factors: More plasma protein binding restricts drug to plasma, hence there will be less distribution to extravascular space and tissues (least V d ). Polar compounds have slightly more volume of distribution (V d : 0.2 L/kg) More tissue binding capacity or more lipid solubility will make drug to cross most of the membranes, including blood–brain barrier making volume of distribution more. Sequestration of drugs in the particular tissue makes its volume of distribution even more than whole blood volume (e.g., Chloroquine has large volume of distribution as it gets sequestered in the liver) Water (0.6 L/kg) Lipid soluble molecules: e.g., Ethanol Extracellular water (0.2 L/kg) Water-soluble molecules: e.g., Gentamicin Polar compounds Blood (0.08 L/kg) Plasma (0.04 L/kg) Strongly plasma protein-bound molecules and very large molecules: e.g., heparin

questions.text: Pediatrician attended an infant with unconjugated serum bilirubin level of 33 mg/dL. The mother might have taken which drug in the third trimester?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Cotrimoxazole

Highyeild:

Cotrimoxazole is a combination of sulfamethoxazole and trimethoprim. Sulfamethoxazole is a Sulfonamide, and combination of a Sulfonamide with an inhibitor of dihydrofolate reductase (trimethoprim or pyrimethamine) provides synergistic activity because of sequential inhibition of folate synthesis. Mother taking sulfonamides in third trimester increases the possibility of child suffering from kernicterus (toxic encephalopathy). This occurs due to the affinity of sulfonamides to bind to proteins (PPB > 90%) which displaces bilirubin from its binding site. As a result, bilirubin can cross the immature blood–brain barrier in fetus leading to toxic effects.

questions.text: For a patient of hypertension on metoprolol, verapamil was given. This will result in:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Bradycardia with AV block

Highyeild:

Impulse generation in the SA node and conduction in AV node are blocked by all calcium channel blockers Sodium channel block is modest with verapamil, and still less marked with diltiazem. It is negligible with dihydropyridines. Verapamil and diltiazem block conduction in cardiac calcium-dependent cells (AV node) more selectively than do the dihydropyridines. Metoprolol is selective β1 blocker which blocks β1 receptors in heart and as a result decreases the heart rate. So combination of metoprolol with verapamil can cause marked decrease in heart rate along with AV block effect. This combination is irrational.

questions.text: Mechanism by which ACh decreases heart rate is:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Delayed diastolic depolarization

Highyeild:

Acetylcholine has following cardiovascular effects: –ve chronotropic effect (↓ Heart rate) –ve dromotropic effect (↓ AV node conduction) –ve ionotropic effect (↓ Force of contraction) ACh has two types of actions: Direct actions and indirect actions. Direct actions: (↓ HCN pacemaker current , ↓ L type calcium current, K current) All of the above direct actions are mediated through direct action of Acetylcholine on M 2 receptors. Decrease in L-type calcium current and increase in potassium current decreases action potential duration and hence decreases cardiac contractility. Whereas decrease in I f funny current via inhibition of HCN channel current leads to decrease in heart rate due to delayed depolarization as spontaneous depolarization in SA node occurs due to funny current via HCN channels. Indirect actions: Gi mediated ↓ cAMP

questions.text: Diamox is given for glaucoma which is a noncompetitive antagonist of carbonic anhydrase. The effect is:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Decrease in Vmax

Highyeild:

Diamox is an acetazolamide (carbonic anhydrase inhibitor). It is a noncompetitive inhibitor of carbonic anhydrase enzyme. It binds to enzyme site which is different from substrate site. In case of noncompetitive inhibitors, inhibition cannot be overcome even on increasing concentration of agonist, and V max decreases with subsequent increase in antagonist concentration. In case of competitive inhibition, as both agonist and antagonist concentration compete for the same binding site, inhibition can be overcome by increasing concentration of agonist and hence VMA remains same in case of increasing agonist in the presence of competitive antagonist.

questions.text: Phase I trial is done to test:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Pharmacokinetics

Highyeild:

Phase I trial is also called First in human trial. In this phase, 10–100 healthy people are enrolled to calculate pharmacokinetic data. Phase 0 trials are also done sometimes prior to phase I studies to calculate early pharmacokinetic data. Phase II and III trials usually enrol patients. Phase II trials enrol 50–100 and usually determine drug efficacy and dose ranging. Phase III trials confirm the efficacy in larger population (100–1000). Phase IV trials are also known as postmarketing studies which determine safety (adverse drug reactions, adverse events, and drug–drug interactions). Even safety of long-term drug treatment can be determined in Phase IV trials which can be missed in clinical trials due to limited duration of clinical trials.

questions.text: Morphine should not be given to a patient with:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Biliary colic

Highyeild:

Opioids (usually morphine) can relieve any type of pain but in some cases of biliary colic, they can aggravate pain due to following reasons. All opioids can cause biliary spasm. Spasm of the sphincter of Oddi elevates amylase and lipase. Atropine only partially prevents morphine-induced biliary spasm, but opioid antagonists prevent or relieve it.

questions.text: What is the important action of nitrates in angina?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Decreases preload

Highyeild:

Nitrates cause release of nitric oxide which causes activation of guanylyl cyclase and through series of steps (via activation of protein kinase and phosphatases) activate myosin light chain through dephosphorylation which causes smooth muscle relaxation and hence vasodilatation. This decreases systemic vascular resistance and there will be increased pooling of blood. All of these events can lead to decrease in preload.

questions.text: A 16-year-old girl was on antiepileptic for treatment of seizure episodes during sleep. She had no seizure since 6 months and NCCT and EEG were normal. What is further management?

options.label: D
options.text: Stop treatment and follow up with 6 monthly EEG

questions.explanation:
Solution:

Continue for 2 years

Highyeild:

Minimum 2-year period of remission is appropriate before planning AED withdrawal. Longer period may be required in adults. If seizures are juvenile myoclonic, then antiepileptic drugs should not be stopped even on normal EEG and NCCT as such seizures can reoccur at any time in future and these seizures never remit permanently. These seizures are usually more common within 30 min–1 hour of awakening. But as seizures asked in above questions were occurring during sleep and are not juvenile myoclonic seizures, antiepileptic drugs withdrawal can be done after 2 years wait provided that EEG and NCCT should have no significant findings.

questions.text: All of the following drugs increase bleeding when given to a patient on warfarin EXCEPT:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Carbamazepine

Highyeild:

Warfarin constitutes S as well as R enantiomers. S Warfarin is the most active form: Metabolism of S warfarin is by CYP2C9 leading to the formation of 7-OH warfarin Metabolism of R warfarin is by CYP1A1, CYP1A2, CYP3A4 leading to the formation of 6-OH warfarin, 8-OH warfarin, 10-OH warfarin As Carbamazepine is enzyme inducer, it induces metabolism of warfarin and hence warfarin concentration decreases and it can lead to therapeutic failure Rest of drugs: Isoniazid, Amiodarone, cimetidine are microsomal enzyme inhibitors leading to warfarin toxicity and can lead to bleeding.
